rules.explanation: An attack that exploits injection of malicious SQL commands to bypass authentication and manipulate databases.

examples.description: Multiple suspicious query attempts with special characters in SQL query fields.
Unauthorized access to protected tables via crafted URL payloads.
Input fields in POST body containing typical SQLi payload patterns.

rules.explanation: An attack where malicious scripts are injected into web content viewed by other users.

examples.description: HTTP requests containing <script> tags in the request body.
Malicious scripts stored in user-generated comments and served to visitors.

rules.explanation: Repeated attempts to guess valid credentials by systematically trying many combinations.

examples.description: Single IP address generates hundreds of failed login attempts in a short timeframe.
Multiple distributed IPs trying a list of common passwords against many usernames.

rules.explanation: An attack to access files and directories outside the webroot using path traversal sequences.

examples.description: Requests containing sequences like '../' to access sensitive filesystem paths.

rules.explanation: A Denial-of-Service attack sending many SYN packets to exhaust server resources.

examples.description: High volume of TCP SYN packets from a set of IP addresses.
Incomplete TCP handshakes from suspicious IPs over a short period.

rules.explanation: Unauthorized automated access to web content for data extraction.

examples.description: High request rate from one source IP accessing the same pages repeatedly.
Requests with missing or unusual user agent headers typical of bots.

rules.explanation: An attack that tricks a user's browser into executing unwanted actions on a web application.

examples.description: HTTP requests with suspicious Origin or Referer headers for sensitive actions.
Unexpected state changes with missing CSRF tokens in form submissions.

rules.rule: Authentication Bypass Due to Weak Passwords
rules.explanation: User accounts compromised due to use of weak or default passwords.

examples.description: Repeated successful logins from various IPs using default or common passwords.
Password change requests failing to reject weak password entries.

rules.explanation: An attack executing arbitrary commands on the host operating system via vulnerable inputs.

examples.description: HTTP requests containing shell metacharacters in file upload names or parameters.
Execution traces showing unexpected shell commands invoked from input parameters.

rules.explanation: A type of DoS attack that holds HTTP connections open by sending partial requests slowly.

examples.description: Many connections with incomplete HTTP request headers over extended durations.
Unusually long keep-alive sessions clogging server resources.
